On Wed, 08 Sep 2004 17:24:12 -0000, dennischang_ca <den_chang@...>  
wrote:

> Hi all,
>
> I thought I would write this because I've been struggling with the
> setup of JUnit for a few hours (yesterday and today). Well I found
> my answer and maybe others are having the same problem and could use
> these hints.
>
> Try:
>
> java junit.textui.TestRunner
>
> and if you get as a response
>
> Usage: TestRunner [-wait] testCaseName, where name is the name of
> the TestCase class
>
> then your good. If not then it's your CLASSPATH.
>
> Now here is the tricky part. When executing say the command "java
> junitfaq.SimpleTest" (code from the JUnit FAQ webpage) you need to
> execute the command from the present working directory where a
> junitfaq directory exists and SimpleTest.class resides within it.
>
> So in other words:
>
> C:/>java junit.textui.TestRunner junit.samples.AllTests
>
> will work if and only if:
>
> C:\junit\samples\AllTests.class
>
> exists.

Glad you finally found this.  However, this is nothing peculiar to JUnit,  
this is a Java thing.  You should Google for "Java classpath" to get some  
links on how to understand the issue.  One article can be found at  
http://www.kevinboone.com/classpath.html.

Hope that helps.

-- 
Jason Rogers
